segment.source: This article shows you how video device controls to enable enhanced photo and video capture scenarios including optical image stabilization and smooth zoom.
segment.target: This article shows you how video device controls to enable enhanced photo and video capture scenarios including optical image stabilization and smooth zoom.

segment.source: Capture device controls for photo and video capture
segment.target: Capture device controls for photo and video capture

segment.source: Capture device controls for photo and video capture
segment.target: Capture device controls for photo and video capture

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article shows you how video device controls to enable enhanced photo and video capture scenarios including optical image stabilization and smooth zoom.
segment.target: This article shows you how video device controls to enable enhanced photo and video capture scenarios including optical image stabilization and smooth zoom.

segment.source: The controls discussed in this article are all added to your app using the same pattern.
segment.target: The controls discussed in this article are all added to your app using the same pattern.

segment.source: First, you check to see if the control is supported on the current device on which your app is running.
segment.target: First, you check to see if the control is supported on the current device on which your app is running.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you set the desired mode for the control.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you set the desired mode for the control.

segment.source: Typically, if a particular control is unsupported on the current device, you should disable or hide the UI element that allows the user to enable the feature.
segment.target: Typically, if a particular control is unsupported on the current device, you should disable or hide the UI element that allows the user to enable the feature.

segment.source: The code in this article was adapted from the Camera Manual Controls SDK sample.
segment.target: The code in this article was adapted from the Camera Manual Controls SDK sample.

segment.source: You can download the sample to see the code used in context or to use the sample as a starting point for your own app.
segment.target: You can download the sample to see the code used in context or to use the sample as a starting point for your own app.

segment.source: Note This article builds on concepts and code discussed in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture, which describes the steps for implementing basic photo and video capture.
segment.target: Note This article builds on concepts and code discussed in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture, which describes the steps for implementing basic photo and video capture.

segment.source: It is recommended that you familiarize yourself with the basic media capture pattern in that article before moving on to more advanced capture scenarios.
segment.target: It is recommended that you familiarize yourself with the basic media capture pattern in that article before moving on to more advanced capture scenarios.

segment.source: The code in this article assumes that your app already has an instance of MediaCapture that has been properly initialized.
segment.target: The code in this article assumes that your app already has an instance of MediaCapture that has been properly initialized.

segment.source: All of the device control APIs discussed in this article are members of the Windows.Media.Devices namespace.
segment.target: All of the device control APIs discussed in this article are members of the Windows.Media.Devices namespace.

segment.source: VideoControllersUsing
segment.target: VideoControllersUsing

segment.source: Exposure
segment.target: Exposure

segment.source: The ExposureControl allows you to set the shutter speed used during photo or video capture.
segment.target: The ExposureControl allows you to set the shutter speed used during photo or video capture.

segment.source: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current exposure value and a checkbox to toggle automatic exposure adjustment.
segment.target: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current exposure value and a checkbox to toggle automatic exposure adjustment.

segment.source: ExposureXAML
segment.target: ExposureXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the ExposureControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the ExposureControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: Set the checked state of the checkbox to indicate if automatic exposure adjustment is currently active to the value of the Auto property.
segment.target: Set the checked state of the checkbox to indicate if automatic exposure adjustment is currently active to the value of the Auto property.

segment.source: The exposure value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.
segment.target: The exposure value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.

segment.source: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.
segment.target: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.

segment.source: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the ExposureControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.
segment.target: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the ExposureControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.

segment.source: ExposureControl
segment.target: ExposureControl

segment.source: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the exposure value by calling SetValueAsync.
segment.target: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the exposure value by calling SetValueAsync.

segment.source: ExposureSlider
segment.target: ExposureSlider

segment.source: In the CheckedChanged event handler of the auto exposure checkbox, turn automatic exposure adjustment on or off by calling SetAutoAsync and passing in a boolean value.
segment.target: In the CheckedChanged event handler of the auto exposure checkbox, turn automatic exposure adjustment on or off by calling SetAutoAsync and passing in a boolean value.

segment.source: ExposureCheckBox
segment.target: ExposureCheckBox

segment.source: Important Automatic exposure mode is only supported while the preview stream is running.
segment.target: Important Automatic exposure mode is only supported while the preview stream is running.

segment.source: Check to make sure that the preview stream is running before turning on automatic exposure.
segment.target: Check to make sure that the preview stream is running before turning on automatic exposure.

segment.source: Exposure compensation
segment.target: Exposure compensation

segment.source: The ExposureCompensationControl allows you to set the exposure compensation used during photo or video capture.
segment.target: The ExposureCompensationControl allows you to set the exposure compensation used during photo or video capture.

segment.source: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current exposure compensation value.
segment.target: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current exposure compensation value.

segment.source: EvXAML
segment.target: EvXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the ExposureCompensationControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the ExposureCompensationControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: The exposure compensation value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.
segment.target: The exposure compensation value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.

segment.source: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.
segment.target: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.

segment.source: Set slider control's value to the current value of the ExposureCompensationControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.
segment.target: Set slider control's value to the current value of the ExposureCompensationControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.

segment.source: EvControl
segment.target: EvControl

segment.source: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the exposure value by calling SetValueAsync.
segment.target: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the exposure value by calling SetValueAsync.

segment.source: EvValueChanged
segment.target: EvValueChanged

segment.source: Flash
segment.target: Flash

segment.source: The FlashControl allows you to enable or disable the flash or to enable automatic flash, where the system dynamically determines whether to use the flash.
segment.target: The FlashControl allows you to enable or disable the flash or to enable automatic flash, where the system dynamically determines whether to use the flash.

segment.source: This control also allows you to enable automatic red eye reduction on devices that support it.
segment.target: This control also allows you to enable automatic red eye reduction on devices that support it.

segment.source: These settings all apply to capturing photos.
segment.target: These settings all apply to capturing photos.

segment.source: The TorchControl is a separate control for turning the torch on or off for video capture.
segment.target: The TorchControl is a separate control for turning the torch on or off for video capture.

segment.source: This example uses a set of radio buttons to allow the user to switch between on, off, and auto flash settings.
segment.target: This example uses a set of radio buttons to allow the user to switch between on, off, and auto flash settings.

segment.source: A checkbox is also provided to allow toggling of red eye reduction and the video torch.
segment.target: A checkbox is also provided to allow toggling of red eye reduction and the video torch.

segment.source: FlashXAML
segment.target: FlashXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FlashControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FlashControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: If the FlashControl is supported, automatic red eye reduction may or may not be supported, so check the RedEyeReductionSupported property before enabling the UI.
segment.target: If the FlashControl is supported, automatic red eye reduction may or may not be supported, so check the RedEyeReductionSupported property before enabling the UI.

segment.source: Since the TorchControl is separate from the flash control, you must also check its Supported property before using it.
segment.target: Since the TorchControl is separate from the flash control, you must also check its Supported property before using it.

segment.source: In the Checked event handler for each of the flash radio buttons, enable or disable the appropriate corresponding flash setting.
segment.target: In the Checked event handler for each of the flash radio buttons, enable or disable the appropriate corresponding flash setting.

segment.source: Note that to set the flash to always be used, you must set the Enabled property to true and the Auto property to false.
segment.target: Note that to set the flash to always be used, you must set the Enabled property to true and the Auto property to false.

segment.source: FlashControl
segment.target: FlashControl

segment.source: FlashRadioButtons
segment.target: FlashRadioButtons

segment.source: In the handler for the red eye reduction checkbox, set the RedEyeReduction property to the appropriate value.
segment.target: In the handler for the red eye reduction checkbox, set the RedEyeReduction property to the appropriate value.

segment.source: RedEye
segment.target: RedEye

segment.source: Finally, in the handler for the video torch checkbox, set the Enabled property to the appropriate value.
segment.target: Finally, in the handler for the video torch checkbox, set the Enabled property to the appropriate value.

segment.source: Torch
segment.target: Torch

segment.source: Note On some devices the torch will not emit light, even if TorchControl.Enabled is set to true, unless the device has a preview stream running and is actively capturing video.
segment.target: Note On some devices the torch will not emit light, even if TorchControl.Enabled is set to true, unless the device has a preview stream running and is actively capturing video.

segment.source: The recommended order of operations is to turn on the video preview, then turn on the torch by setting Enabled to true, and then initiate video capture.
segment.target: The recommended order of operations is to turn on the video preview, then turn on the torch by setting Enabled to true, and then initiate video capture.

segment.source: On some devices the torch will light up after the preview is started.
segment.target: On some devices the torch will light up after the preview is started.

segment.source: On other devices, the torch may not light up until video capture is started.
segment.target: On other devices, the torch may not light up until video capture is started.

segment.source: Focus
segment.target: Focus

segment.source: Three different commonly used methods for adjusting the focus of the camera are supported by the FocusControl object, continuous autofocus, tap to focus, and manual focus.
segment.target: Three different commonly used methods for adjusting the focus of the camera are supported by the FocusControl object, continuous autofocus, tap to focus, and manual focus.

segment.source: A camera app may support all three of these methods, but for readability, this article discusses each technique separately.
segment.target: A camera app may support all three of these methods, but for readability, this article discusses each technique separately.

segment.source: This section also discusses how to enable the focus assist light.
segment.target: This section also discusses how to enable the focus assist light.

segment.source: Continuous autofocus
segment.target: Continuous autofocus

segment.source: Enabling continuous autofocus instructs the camera to adjust the focus dynamically to try to keep the subject of the photo or video in focus.
segment.target: Enabling continuous autofocus instructs the camera to adjust the focus dynamically to try to keep the subject of the photo or video in focus.

segment.source: This example uses a radio button to toggle continuous autofocus on and off.
segment.target: This example uses a radio button to toggle continuous autofocus on and off.

segment.source: CAFXAML
segment.target: CAFXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FocusControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FocusControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: Then, see if continuous autofocus is supported by checking the SupportedFocusModes list to see if it contains the value FocusMode.Continuous, and if so, show the continuous autofocus radio button.
segment.target: Then, see if continuous autofocus is supported by checking the SupportedFocusModes list to see if it contains the value FocusMode.Continuous, and if so, show the continuous autofocus radio button.

segment.source: CAF
segment.target: CAF

segment.source: In the Checked event handler for the continuous autofocus radio button, use the VideoDeviceController.FocusControl property to get an instance of the control.
segment.target: In the Checked event handler for the continuous autofocus radio button, use the VideoDeviceController.FocusControl property to get an instance of the control.

segment.source: Call UnlockAsync to unlock the control in case your app has previously called LockAsync to enable one of the other focus modes.
segment.target: Call UnlockAsync to unlock the control in case your app has previously called LockAsync to enable one of the other focus modes.

segment.source: Create a new FocusSettings object and set the Mode property to Continuous.
segment.target: Create a new FocusSettings object and set the Mode property to Continuous.

segment.source: Set the AutoFocusRange property to a value appropriate for your app scenario or selected by the user from your UI.
segment.target: Set the AutoFocusRange property to a value appropriate for your app scenario or selected by the user from your UI.

segment.source: Pass your FocusSettings object into the Configure method and then call FocusAsync to initiate continuous autofocus.
segment.target: Pass your FocusSettings object into the Configure method and then call FocusAsync to initiate continuous autofocus.

segment.source: CafFocusRadioButton
segment.target: CafFocusRadioButton

segment.source: Important Autofocus mode is only supported while the preview stream is running.
segment.target: Important Autofocus mode is only supported while the preview stream is running.

segment.source: Check to make sure that the preview stream is running before turning on continuous autofocus.
segment.target: Check to make sure that the preview stream is running before turning on continuous autofocus.

segment.source: Tap to focus
segment.target: Tap to focus

segment.source: The tap-to-focus technique uses the FocusControl and the RegionsOfInterestControl to specify a subregion of the capture frame where the capture device should focus.
segment.target: The tap-to-focus technique uses the FocusControl and the RegionsOfInterestControl to specify a subregion of the capture frame where the capture device should focus.

segment.source: The region of focus is determined by the user tapping on the screen displaying the preview stream.
segment.target: The region of focus is determined by the user tapping on the screen displaying the preview stream.

segment.source: This example uses a radio button to enable and disable tap-to-focus mode.
segment.target: This example uses a radio button to enable and disable tap-to-focus mode.

segment.source: TapFocusXAML
segment.target: TapFocusXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FocusControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FocusControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: The RegionsOfInterestControl must be supported, and must support at least one region, in order to use this technique.
segment.target: The RegionsOfInterestControl must be supported, and must support at least one region, in order to use this technique.

segment.source: Check the AutoFocusSupported and MaxRegions properties to determine whether to show or hide the radio button for tap-to-focus.
segment.target: Check the AutoFocusSupported and MaxRegions properties to determine whether to show or hide the radio button for tap-to-focus.

segment.source: TapFocus
segment.target: TapFocus

segment.source: In the Checked event handler for the tap-to-focus radio button, use the VideoDeviceController.FocusControl property to get an instance of the control.
segment.target: In the Checked event handler for the tap-to-focus radio button, use the VideoDeviceController.FocusControl property to get an instance of the control.

segment.source: Call LockAsync to lock the control in case your app has previously called UnlockAsync to enable continuous autofocus.
segment.target: Call LockAsync to lock the control in case your app has previously called UnlockAsync to enable continuous autofocus.

segment.source: Then you wait for the user to tap the screen to change the focus.
segment.target: Then you wait for the user to tap the screen to change the focus.

segment.source: TapFocusRadioButton
segment.target: TapFocusRadioButton

segment.source: This example focuses on a region when the user taps the screen, and then removes the focus from that region when the user taps again, like a toggle.
segment.target: This example focuses on a region when the user taps the screen, and then removes the focus from that region when the user taps again, like a toggle.

segment.source: Use a boolean variable to track the current toggled state.
segment.target: Use a boolean variable to track the current toggled state.

segment.source: IsFocused
segment.target: IsFocused

segment.source: The next step is to listen for the event when the user taps the screen by handling the Tapped event of the CaptureElement that is currently displaying the capture preview stream.
segment.target: The next step is to listen for the event when the user taps the screen by handling the Tapped event of the CaptureElement that is currently displaying the capture preview stream.

segment.source: If the camera isn't currently previewing, or if tap-to-focus mode is disabled, then return from the handler without doing anything.
segment.target: If the camera isn't currently previewing, or if tap-to-focus mode is disabled, then return from the handler without doing anything.

segment.source: If the tracking variable \_isFocused is toggled to false and if the camera isn't currently in the process of focus - determined by the FocusState property of the FocusControl - then begin the tap-to-focus process.
segment.target: If the tracking variable \_isFocused is toggled to false and if the camera isn't currently in the process of focus - determined by the FocusState property of the FocusControl - then begin the tap-to-focus process.

segment.source: Get the position of the user's tap from the event args passed into the handler.
segment.target: Get the position of the user's tap from the event args passed into the handler.

segment.source: This example also uses this opportunity to pick the size of the region that will be focused upon.
segment.target: This example also uses this opportunity to pick the size of the region that will be focused upon.

segment.source: In this case, the size is 1/4 of the smallest dimension of the capture element.
segment.target: In this case, the size is 1/4 of the smallest dimension of the capture element.

segment.source: Pass the tap position and the region size into the TapToFocus helper method that is defined in the next section.
segment.target: Pass the tap position and the region size into the TapToFocus helper method that is defined in the next section.

segment.source: If the \_isFocused toggle is set to true, then the user tap should clear the focus from the previous region.
segment.target: If the \_isFocused toggle is set to true, then the user tap should clear the focus from the previous region.

segment.source: This is done in the TapUnfocus helper method shown below.
segment.target: This is done in the TapUnfocus helper method shown below.

segment.source: TapFocusPreviewControl
segment.target: TapFocusPreviewControl

segment.source: In the TapToFocus helper method, first set the \_isFocused toggle to true so that the next screen tap will release the focus from the tapped region.
segment.target: In the TapToFocus helper method, first set the \_isFocused toggle to true so that the next screen tap will release the focus from the tapped region.

segment.source: The next task in this helper method is to determine the rectangle within the preview stream that will be assigned to the focus control.
segment.target: The next task in this helper method is to determine the rectangle within the preview stream that will be assigned to the focus control.

segment.source: This requires two steps.
segment.target: This requires two steps.

segment.source: The first step is to determine the rectangle that the preview stream takes up within the CaptureElement control.
segment.target: The first step is to determine the rectangle that the preview stream takes up within the CaptureElement control.

segment.source: This depends on the dimensions of the preview stream and the orientation of the device.
segment.target: This depends on the dimensions of the preview stream and the orientation of the device.

segment.source: The helper method GetPreviewStreamRectInControl, shown at the end of this section, performs this task and returns the rectangle containing the preview stream.
segment.target: The helper method GetPreviewStreamRectInControl, shown at the end of this section, performs this task and returns the rectangle containing the preview stream.

segment.source: The next task in TapToFocus is to convert the tap location and desired focus rectangle size, which were determined within the CaptureElement.Tapped event handler, into coordinates within capture stream.
segment.target: The next task in TapToFocus is to convert the tap location and desired focus rectangle size, which were determined within the CaptureElement.Tapped event handler, into coordinates within capture stream.

segment.source: The ConvertUiTapToPreviewRect helper method, shown later in this section, performs this conversion and returns the rectangle, in capture stream coordinates, where the focus will be requested.
segment.target: The ConvertUiTapToPreviewRect helper method, shown later in this section, performs this conversion and returns the rectangle, in capture stream coordinates, where the focus will be requested.

segment.source: Now that the target rectangle has been obtained, create a new RegionOfInterest object, setting the Bounds property to the target rectangle obtained in the previous steps.
segment.target: Now that the target rectangle has been obtained, create a new RegionOfInterest object, setting the Bounds property to the target rectangle obtained in the previous steps.

segment.source: Get the capture device's FocusControl.
segment.target: Get the capture device's FocusControl.

segment.source: Create a new FocusSettings object and set the Mode and AutoFocusRange to your desired values, after checking to make sure that they are supported by the FocusControl.
segment.target: Create a new FocusSettings object and set the Mode and AutoFocusRange to your desired values, after checking to make sure that they are supported by the FocusControl.

segment.source: Call Configure on the FocusControl to make your settings active and signal the device to begin focusing on the specified region.
segment.target: Call Configure on the FocusControl to make your settings active and signal the device to begin focusing on the specified region.

segment.source: Next, get the capture device's RegionsOfInterestControl and call SetRegionsAsync to set the active region.
segment.target: Next, get the capture device's RegionsOfInterestControl and call SetRegionsAsync to set the active region.

segment.source: Multiple regions of interest can be set on devices that support it, but this example only sets a single region.
segment.target: Multiple regions of interest can be set on devices that support it, but this example only sets a single region.

segment.source: Finally, call FocusAsync on the FocusControl to initiate focusing.
segment.target: Finally, call FocusAsync on the FocusControl to initiate focusing.

segment.source: Important When implementing tap to focus, the order of operations is important.
segment.target: Important When implementing tap to focus, the order of operations is important.

segment.source: You should call these APIs in the following order:
segment.target: You should call these APIs in the following order:

segment.source: TapToFocus
segment.target: TapToFocus

segment.source: In the TapUnfocus helper method, obtain the RegionsOfInterestControl and call ClearRegionsAsync to clear the region that was registered with the control within the TapToFocus helper method.
segment.target: In the TapUnfocus helper method, obtain the RegionsOfInterestControl and call ClearRegionsAsync to clear the region that was registered with the control within the TapToFocus helper method.

segment.source: Then, get the FocusControl and call FocusAsync to cause the device to refocus without a region of interest.
segment.target: Then, get the FocusControl and call FocusAsync to cause the device to refocus without a region of interest.

segment.source: TapUnfocus
segment.target: TapUnfocus

segment.source: The GetPreviewStreamRectInControl helper method uses the resolution of the preview stream and the orientation of the device to determine the rectangle within the preview element that contains the preview stream, trimming off any letterboxed padding that the control may provide to maintain the stream's aspect ratio.
segment.target: The GetPreviewStreamRectInControl helper method uses the resolution of the preview stream and the orientation of the device to determine the rectangle within the preview element that contains the preview stream, trimming off any letterboxed padding that the control may provide to maintain the stream's aspect ratio.

segment.source: This method uses class member variables defined in the basic media capture example code found in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture.
segment.target: This method uses class member variables defined in the basic media capture example code found in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture.

segment.source: GetPreviewStreamRectInControl
segment.target: GetPreviewStreamRectInControl

segment.source: The ConvertUiTapToPreviewRect helper method takes as arguments the location of the tap event, the desired size of the focus region, and the rectangle containing the preview stream obtained from the GetPreviewStreamRectInControl helper method.
segment.target: The ConvertUiTapToPreviewRect helper method takes as arguments the location of the tap event, the desired size of the focus region, and the rectangle containing the preview stream obtained from the GetPreviewStreamRectInControl helper method.

segment.source: This method uses these values and the device's current orientation to calculate the rectangle within the preview stream that contains the desired region.
segment.target: This method uses these values and the device's current orientation to calculate the rectangle within the preview stream that contains the desired region.

segment.source: Once again, this method uses class member variables defined in the basic media capture example code found in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture.
segment.target: Once again, this method uses class member variables defined in the basic media capture example code found in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture.

segment.source: ConvertUiTapToPreviewRect
segment.target: ConvertUiTapToPreviewRect

segment.source: Manual focus
segment.target: Manual focus

segment.source: The manual focus technique uses a Slider control to set the current focus depth of the capture device.
segment.target: The manual focus technique uses a Slider control to set the current focus depth of the capture device.

segment.source: A radio button is used to toggle manual focus on and off.
segment.target: A radio button is used to toggle manual focus on and off.

segment.source: ManualFocusXAML
segment.target: ManualFocusXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FocusControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FocusControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: The focus value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.
segment.target: The focus value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.

segment.source: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.
segment.target: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.

segment.source: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the FocusControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.
segment.target: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the FocusControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.

segment.source: Focus
segment.target: Focus

segment.source: In the Checked event handler for the manual focus radio button, get the FocusControl object and call LockAsync in case your app had previously unlocked the focus with a call to UnlockAsync.
segment.target: In the Checked event handler for the manual focus radio button, get the FocusControl object and call LockAsync in case your app had previously unlocked the focus with a call to UnlockAsync.

segment.source: ManualFocusChecked
segment.target: ManualFocusChecked

segment.source: In the ValueChanged event handler of the manual focus slider, get the current value of the control and the set the focus value by calling SetValueAsync.
segment.target: In the ValueChanged event handler of the manual focus slider, get the current value of the control and the set the focus value by calling SetValueAsync.

segment.source: FocusSlider
segment.target: FocusSlider

segment.source: Enable the focus light
segment.target: Enable the focus light

segment.source: On devices that support it, you can enable a focus assist light to help the device focus.
segment.target: On devices that support it, you can enable a focus assist light to help the device focus.

segment.source: This example uses a checkbox to enable or disable the focus assist light.
segment.target: This example uses a checkbox to enable or disable the focus assist light.

segment.source: FocusLightXAML
segment.target: FocusLightXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FlashControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the FlashControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: Also check the AssistantLightSupported to make sure the assist light is also supported.
segment.target: Also check the AssistantLightSupported to make sure the assist light is also supported.

segment.source: If these are both supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If these are both supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: FocusLight
segment.target: FocusLight

segment.source: In the CheckedChanged event handler, get the capture devices FlashControl object.
segment.target: In the CheckedChanged event handler, get the capture devices FlashControl object.

segment.source: Set the AssistantLightEnabled property to enable or disable the focus light.
segment.target: Set the AssistantLightEnabled property to enable or disable the focus light.

segment.source: FocusLightCheckBox
segment.target: FocusLightCheckBox

segment.source: ISO speed
segment.target: ISO speed

segment.source: The IsoSpeedControl allows you to set the ISO speed used during photo or video capture.
segment.target: The IsoSpeedControl allows you to set the ISO speed used during photo or video capture.

segment.source: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current exposure compensation value and a checkbox to toggle automatic ISO speed adjustment.
segment.target: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current exposure compensation value and a checkbox to toggle automatic ISO speed adjustment.

segment.source: IsoXAML
segment.target: IsoXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the IsoSpeedControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the IsoSpeedControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: Set the checked state of the checkbox to indicate if automatic ISO speed adjustment is currently active to the value of the Auto property.
segment.target: Set the checked state of the checkbox to indicate if automatic ISO speed adjustment is currently active to the value of the Auto property.

segment.source: The ISO speed value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.
segment.target: The ISO speed value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.

segment.source: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.
segment.target: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.

segment.source: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the IsoSpeedControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.
segment.target: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the IsoSpeedControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.

segment.source: IsoControl
segment.target: IsoControl

segment.source: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the ISO speed value by calling SetValueAsync.
segment.target: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the ISO speed value by calling SetValueAsync.

segment.source: IsoSlider
segment.target: IsoSlider

segment.source: In the CheckedChanged event handler of the auto ISO speed checkbox, turn on automatic ISO speed adjustment by calling SetAutoAsync.
segment.target: In the CheckedChanged event handler of the auto ISO speed checkbox, turn on automatic ISO speed adjustment by calling SetAutoAsync.

segment.source: Turn automatic ISO speed adjustment off by calling SetValueAsync and passing in the current value of the slider control.
segment.target: Turn automatic ISO speed adjustment off by calling SetValueAsync and passing in the current value of the slider control.

segment.source: IsoCheckBox
segment.target: IsoCheckBox

segment.source: Optical image stabilization
segment.target: Optical image stabilization

segment.source: Optical image stabilization (OIS) stabilizes a the captured video stream by mechanically manipulating the hardware capture device, which can provide a superior result than digital stabilization.
segment.target: Optical image stabilization (OIS) stabilizes a the captured video stream by mechanically manipulating the hardware capture device, which can provide a superior result than digital stabilization.

segment.source: On devices that don't support OIS, you can use the VideoStabilizationEffect to perform digital stabilization on your captured vide.
segment.target: On devices that don't support OIS, you can use the VideoStabilizationEffect to perform digital stabilization on your captured vide.

segment.source: For more information, see Effects for video capture.
segment.target: For more information, see Effects for video capture.

segment.source: Determine if OIS is supported on the current device by checking the OpticalImageStabilizationControl.Supported property.
segment.target: Determine if OIS is supported on the current device by checking the OpticalImageStabilizationControl.Supported property.

segment.source: The OIS control supports three modes: on, off, and automatic, which means that the device dynamically determines if OIS would improve the media capture and, if so, enables OIS.
segment.target: The OIS control supports three modes: on, off, and automatic, which means that the device dynamically determines if OIS would improve the media capture and, if so, enables OIS.

segment.source: To determine if a particular mode is supported on a device, check to see if the OpticalImageStabilizationControl.SupportedModes collection contains the desired mode.
segment.target: To determine if a particular mode is supported on a device, check to see if the OpticalImageStabilizationControl.SupportedModes collection contains the desired mode.

segment.source: Enable or disable OIS by setting the OpticalImageStabilizationControl.Mode to the desired mode.
segment.target: Enable or disable OIS by setting the OpticalImageStabilizationControl.Mode to the desired mode.

segment.source: SetOpticalImageStabilizationMode
segment.target: SetOpticalImageStabilizationMode

segment.source: White balance
segment.target: White balance

segment.source: The WhiteBalanceControl allows you to set the white balance used during photo or video capture.
segment.target: The WhiteBalanceControl allows you to set the white balance used during photo or video capture.

segment.source: This example uses a ComboBox control to select from built-in color temperature presets and a Slider control for manual white balance adjustment.
segment.target: This example uses a ComboBox control to select from built-in color temperature presets and a Slider control for manual white balance adjustment.

segment.source: WhiteBalanceXAML
segment.target: WhiteBalanceXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the WhiteBalanceControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the WhiteBalanceControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: Set the items of the combo box to the values of the ColorTemperaturePreset enumeration.
segment.target: Set the items of the combo box to the values of the ColorTemperaturePreset enumeration.

segment.source: And set the selected item to the current value of the Preset property.
segment.target: And set the selected item to the current value of the Preset property.

segment.source: For manual control, the white balance value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.
segment.target: For manual control, the white balance value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.

segment.source: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.
segment.target: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.

segment.source: Before enabling manual control, check to make sure that the range between the minimum and maximum supported values is greater than the step size.
segment.target: Before enabling manual control, check to make sure that the range between the minimum and maximum supported values is greater than the step size.

segment.source: If it is not, manual control is not supported on the current device.
segment.target: If it is not, manual control is not supported on the current device.

segment.source: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the WhiteBalanceControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.
segment.target: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the WhiteBalanceControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.

segment.source: WhiteBalance
segment.target: WhiteBalance

segment.source: In the SelectionChanged event handler of the color temperature preset combo box, get the currently selected preset and set the value of the control by calling SetPresetAsync.
segment.target: In the SelectionChanged event handler of the color temperature preset combo box, get the currently selected preset and set the value of the control by calling SetPresetAsync.

segment.source: If the selected preset value is not Manual, then disable the manual white balance slider.
segment.target: If the selected preset value is not Manual, then disable the manual white balance slider.

segment.source: WhiteBalanceComboBox
segment.target: WhiteBalanceComboBox

segment.source: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the white balance value by calling SetValueAsync.
segment.target: In the ValueChanged event handler, get the current value of the control and the set the white balance value by calling SetValueAsync.

segment.source: WhiteBalanceSlider
segment.target: WhiteBalanceSlider

segment.source: Important Adjusting the white balance is only supported while the preview stream is running.
segment.target: Important Adjusting the white balance is only supported while the preview stream is running.

segment.source: Check to make sure that the preview stream is running before setting the white balance value or preset.
segment.target: Check to make sure that the preview stream is running before setting the white balance value or preset.

segment.source: Important The ColorTemperaturePreset.Auto preset value instructs the system to automatically adjust the white balance level.
segment.target: Important The ColorTemperaturePreset.Auto preset value instructs the system to automatically adjust the white balance level.

segment.source: For some scenarios, such as capturing a photo sequence where the white balance levels should be the same for each frame, you may want to lock the control to the current automatic value.
segment.target: For some scenarios, such as capturing a photo sequence where the white balance levels should be the same for each frame, you may want to lock the control to the current automatic value.

segment.source: To do this, call SetPresetAsync and specify the Manual preset and do not set a value on the control using SetValueAsync.
segment.target: To do this, call SetPresetAsync and specify the Manual preset and do not set a value on the control using SetValueAsync.

segment.source: This will cause the device to lock the current value.
segment.target: This will cause the device to lock the current value.

segment.source: Do not attempt to read the current control value and then pass the returned value into SetValueAsync because this value is not guaranteed to be correct.
segment.target: Do not attempt to read the current control value and then pass the returned value into SetValueAsync because this value is not guaranteed to be correct.

segment.source: Zoom
segment.target: Zoom

segment.source: The ZoomControl allows you to set the zoom level used during photo or video capture.
segment.target: The ZoomControl allows you to set the zoom level used during photo or video capture.

segment.source: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current zoom level.
segment.target: This example uses a Slider control to adjust the current zoom level.

segment.source: The following section shows how to adjust zoom based on a pinch gesture on the screen.
segment.target: The following section shows how to adjust zoom based on a pinch gesture on the screen.

segment.source: ZoomXAML
segment.target: ZoomXAML

segment.source: Check to see if the current capture device supports the ZoomControl by checking the Supported property.
segment.target: Check to see if the current capture device supports the ZoomControl by checking the Supported property.

segment.source: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.
segment.target: If the control is supported, then you can show and enable the UI for this feature.

segment.source: The zoom level value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.
segment.target: The zoom level value must be within the range supported by the device and must be an increment of the supported step size.

segment.source: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.
segment.target: Get the supported values for the current device by checking the Min, Max, and Step properties, which are used to set the corresponding properties of the slider control.

segment.source: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the ZoomControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.
segment.target: Set the slider control's value to the current value of the ZoomControl after unregistering the ValueChanged event handler so that the event is not triggered when the value is set.

segment.source: ZoomControl
segment.target: ZoomControl

segment.source: In the ValueChanged event handler, create a new instance of the ZoomSettings class, setting the Value property to the current value of the zoom slider control.
segment.target: In the ValueChanged event handler, create a new instance of the ZoomSettings class, setting the Value property to the current value of the zoom slider control.

segment.source: If the SupportedModes property of the ZoomControl contains ZoomTransitionMode.Smooth, it means the device supports smooth transitions between zoom levels.
segment.target: If the SupportedModes property of the ZoomControl contains ZoomTransitionMode.Smooth, it means the device supports smooth transitions between zoom levels.

segment.source: Since this modes provides a better user experience, you will typically want to use this value for the Mode property of the ZoomSettings object.
segment.target: Since this modes provides a better user experience, you will typically want to use this value for the Mode property of the ZoomSettings object.

segment.source: Finally, change the current zoom settings by passing your ZoomSettings object into the Configure method of the ZoomControl object.
segment.target: Finally, change the current zoom settings by passing your ZoomSettings object into the Configure method of the ZoomControl object.

segment.source: ZoomSlider
segment.target: ZoomSlider

segment.source: Smooth zoom using pinch gesture
segment.target: Smooth zoom using pinch gesture

segment.source: As discussed in the previous section, on devices that support it, smooth zoom mode allows the capture device to smoothly transition between digital zoom levels, allowing the user to dynamically adjust the zoom level during the capture operation without discrete and jarring transitions.
segment.target: As discussed in the previous section, on devices that support it, smooth zoom mode allows the capture device to smoothly transition between digital zoom levels, allowing the user to dynamically adjust the zoom level during the capture operation without discrete and jarring transitions.

segment.source: This section describes how to adjust the zoom level in response to a pinch gesture.
segment.target: This section describes how to adjust the zoom level in response to a pinch gesture.

segment.source: First, determine if the digital zoom control is supported on the current device by checking the ZoomControl.Supported property.
segment.target: First, determine if the digital zoom control is supported on the current device by checking the ZoomControl.Supported property.

segment.source: Next, determine if smooth zoom mode is available by checking the ZoomControl.SupportedModes to see if it contains the value ZoomTransitionMode.Smooth.
segment.target: Next, determine if smooth zoom mode is available by checking the ZoomControl.SupportedModes to see if it contains the value ZoomTransitionMode.Smooth.

segment.source: IsSmoothZoomSupported
segment.target: IsSmoothZoomSupported

segment.source: On a multi-touch enabled device, a typical scenario is to adjust the zoom factor based on a two-finger pinch gesture.
segment.target: On a multi-touch enabled device, a typical scenario is to adjust the zoom factor based on a two-finger pinch gesture.

segment.source: Set the ManipulationMode property of the CaptureElement control to ManipulationModes.Scale to enable the pinch gesture.
segment.target: Set the ManipulationMode property of the CaptureElement control to ManipulationModes.Scale to enable the pinch gesture.

segment.source: Then, register for the ManipulationDelta event which is raised when the pinch gesture changes size.
segment.target: Then, register for the ManipulationDelta event which is raised when the pinch gesture changes size.

segment.source: RegisterPinchGestureHandler
segment.target: RegisterPinchGestureHandler

segment.source: In the handler for the ManipulationDelta event, update the zoom factor based on the change in the user's pinch gesture.
segment.target: In the handler for the ManipulationDelta event, update the zoom factor based on the change in the user's pinch gesture.

segment.source: The ManipulationDelta.Scale value represents the change in scale of the pinch gesture such that a small increase in the size of the pinch is a number slightly larger than 1.0 and a small decrease in the pinch size is a number slightly smaller than 1.0.
segment.target: The ManipulationDelta.Scale value represents the change in scale of the pinch gesture such that a small increase in the size of the pinch is a number slightly larger than 1.0 and a small decrease in the pinch size is a number slightly smaller than 1.0.

segment.source: In this example, the current value of the zoom control is multiplied by the scale delta.
segment.target: In this example, the current value of the zoom control is multiplied by the scale delta.

segment.source: Before setting the zoom factor, you must make sure that the value is not less than the minimum value supported by the device as indicated by the ZoomControl.Min property.
segment.target: Before setting the zoom factor, you must make sure that the value is not less than the minimum value supported by the device as indicated by the ZoomControl.Min property.

segment.source: Also, make sure that the value is less than or equal to the ZoomControl.Max value.
segment.target: Also, make sure that the value is less than or equal to the ZoomControl.Max value.

segment.source: Finally, you must make sure that the the zoom factor is a multiple of the zoom step size supported by the device as indicated by the Step property.
segment.target: Finally, you must make sure that the the zoom factor is a multiple of the zoom step size supported by the device as indicated by the Step property.

segment.source: If your zoom factor does not meet these requirements, an exception will be thrown when you attempt to set the zoom level on the capture device.
segment.target: If your zoom factor does not meet these requirements, an exception will be thrown when you attempt to set the zoom level on the capture device.

segment.source: Set the zoom level on the capture device by creating a new ZoomSettings object.
segment.target: Set the zoom level on the capture device by creating a new ZoomSettings object.

segment.source: Set the Mode property to ZoomTransitionMode.Smooth and then set the Value property to your desired zoom factor.
segment.target: Set the Mode property to ZoomTransitionMode.Smooth and then set the Value property to your desired zoom factor.

segment.source: Finally, call ZoomControl.Configure to set the new zoom value on the device.
segment.target: Finally, call ZoomControl.Configure to set the new zoom value on the device.

segment.source: The device will smoothly transition to the new zoom value.
segment.target: The device will smoothly transition to the new zoom value.

segment.source: ManipulationDelta
segment.target: ManipulationDelta

segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Capture photos and video with MediaCapture
segment.target: Capture photos and video with MediaCapture
